case_name: State of Punjab v. Respondent Nos. 1 and 2

facts.text: Erstwhile Pepsu government decided to allot land measuring 89 canals 5 biswas situated in village Magha to Smt. Bachan Kaur, widow of late Jangir Singh, for maintenance during her lifetime in lieu of meritorious services rendered by late Jangir Singh, Havaldar in Sikh regiment

anchor.surface_text: The erstwhile Pepsu government in lieu of meritorious services rendered by late Jangir Singh, Havaldar in Sikh regiment decided to allot land measuring 89 canals 5 biswas situated in village Magha to Smt. Bachan Kaur, widow of late Jangir Singh for maintenance during her lifetime.

facts.text: On 1.4.52, the deputy commissioner, Sangrur allotted the land to Smt. Bachan Kaur in pursuance of the decision of the then government

anchor.surface_text: On 1.4.52, the deputy companymissioner, Sangrur in pursuance of the decision of the then government, allotted the land to Smt. Bachan Kaur.

facts.text: The allotment order indicated that Smt. Bachan Kaur shall have only life estate in the said land

anchor.surface_text: The allotment order indicated that Smt. Bachan Kaur shall have only life estate in the said land.

facts.text: Smt. Bachan Kaur came into possession over the said land in pursuance of the said order of allotment

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the said order of allotment, Smt. Bachan 1 Kaur came into possession over the said land.

facts.text: On 10.2.64, Smt. Bachan Kaur executed a registered sale deed in favour of respondent Nos. 1 and 2 in respect of the said land for a consideration of Rs. 24,000/-

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on 10.2.64, Smt. Bachan Kaur executed a registered sale deed in favour of respondent Nos. 1 and 2 in respect of the said land allotted to her for a companysideration of amount of Rs. 24,000/-

facts.text: Respondent Nos. 1 and 2 came into possession over the said land in pursuance of the said sale deed

anchor.surface_text: . It further appears that in pursuance of the said sale deed, respondent Nos. 1 and 2 came into possession over the said land.

facts.text: The said respondents applied for mutation of their names in the revenue records, which was granted

anchor.surface_text: The said respondents also applied for mutation of their names in the revenue records, which was granted.

facts.text: The State of Punjab filed an objection against the said mutation, which was allowed

anchor.surface_text: However, the State of Punjab filed an objection against the said mutation, which was allowed.

facts.text: On appeal before the financial commissioner, the order was set aside and the parties were directed to establish their right in the civil court

anchor.surface_text: On appeal before the financial companymissioner, the order was set aside and the parties were directed to establish their right in the civil companyrt.

facts.text: The State of Punjab instituted a civil suit on 2.9.74 for a declaration that the sale deed executed by Smt. Bachan Kaur in favour of respondent Nos. 1 and 2 is illegal and void and does not confer any title on these vendees

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the aforesaid order, the State of Punjab instituted a civil suit on 2.9.74 for a declaration that the sale deed executed by Smt. Bachan Kaur in favour of respondent Nos. 1 and 2 is illegal and void and the same does number companyfer any title on these vendees.

facts.text: Respondent Nos. 1 and 2 were arraigned as defendants in the said suit along with Smt. Bachan Kaur

anchor.surface_text: Respondent number. 1 and 2 were arraigned as defendants in the said suit along with Smt. Bachan Kaur,

facts.text: Respondent Nos. 1 and 2 filed a separate written statement wherein they took the plea that they being bona fide purchasers of the land for consideration have acquired title under Section 41 of the Transfer of Property Act

anchor.surface_text: Respondent number. 1 and 2 filed a separate written statement, wherein they took the plea that they being the bona fide purchaser of the land for companysideration, have acquired title under Section 41 of the Transfer of Property Act.

facts.text: The trial court decreed the suit

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt framed several issues and after companysidering the matter, decreed the suit.

facts.text: Aggrieved respondents preferred an appeal before the first appellate court against the decree of the trial court, which was dismissed

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved respondents preferred an appeal before the first appellate companyrt against the decree of the trial companyrt, which was dismissed.

facts.text: The respondents preferred a second appeal before the High Court

anchor.surface_text: The respondents thereafter preferred a second appeal before the High Court,

facts.text: The High Court allowed the appeal preferred by the respondents and set aside the decree affirmed by the first appellate court

anchor.surface_text: In view of that matter, the appeal preferred by the respondents were allowed and the decree affirmed by the first appellate companyrt was set aside.

facts.text: The State of Punjab is in appeal before the Supreme Court against the said judgment of the High Court

anchor.surface_text: It is against the said judgment of the High Court, the State of Punjab is in appeal before us.

facts.text: Ms. Monika Gusain, learned counsel for the State of Punjab urged that the widow having limited right during her lifetime could not have transferred the interest in the land beyond her lifetime

anchor.surface_text: Ms. Monika Gusain, learned companynsel appearing for the State of Punjab urged that since the widow having limited right during her lifetime, she companyld number have transferred the interest in the land beyond her lifetime.

facts.text: Ms. Amita Gupta, learned counsel for the respondents argued that the respondents being bona fide purchasers from ostensible owners for consideration and in good faith, the sale deed is valid under Section 41 of the Transfer of Property Act

anchor.surface_text: Ms. Amita Gupta, learned companynsel for the respondents, however, argued that the respondents being bona fide purchasers from ostensible owners for a companysideration and in good faith, the sale deed is valid under Section 41 of the Transfer of Property Act  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Admittedly, Smt. Bachan Kaur had a life estate in the property and after her death, the title in the land would revert to the State of Punjab

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, she had a life estate in the Property and after her death, the title in the land would revert to the Slate of Punjab.

facts.text: The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the order and judgment of the High Court and affirmed the decree of the trial court

anchor.surface_text: In view of the matter, the appeal deserves to be allowed. The order and judgment of the High Court is set aside and the decree of the trial companyrt is affirmed.
